Tel.: +82 31 249 9733; fax: +82 31 254 4905. Graphical abstract Mechanochemical treatments can change the physicochemical characteristics of catalysts. Attrition milling was utilized in the preparation of catalysts from V2O5 and anatase TiO2, and the catalysts were applied for the study of selective catalytic oxidation (SCO). Catalysts comprising 2wt% V/Ti were prepared by mechanochemical methods using different milling times, and these catalysts were used for the SCO of NH3 to N2. The optimal calcination milling time was 3h. The 2wt% V/Ti catalyst prepared by attrition milling for 3h (VTi-A.M3; where A.M in the catalyst name denotes attrition milling, and 3 is the milling time applied) gave rise to the highest N2 yield (∼82%) at 250°C. The dry attrition milling method is a dry method for the synthesis of the SCO catalyst, involving a combination of V2O5 and TiO2 powder. The properties of the catalyst were studied using physiochemical analyses, including BET surface area, X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR). Anatase, which is a metastable phase, underwent transformation into TiO2(II) due to the milling effect. The highest N2 yield was achieved when the TiO2 crystallite size of the catalyst was 16nm. The content of pentavalent vanadium species increased due to the milling effect. A correlation was identified between the V5+ species and the catalyst N2 yield. VTi-A.M3 was found to lead to high-level selective catalytic oxidation of NH3, with active internal selective catalytic reduction (SCR) because of the presence of highly dispersed V5+ on the catalyst surface. The dry attrition milling method can be used to control the dispersion of vanadium on the catalyst surface, which can in turn improve the N2 yield activity by increasing the ratio of V5+ species. Keywords Vanadium/titania SCO Ammonia oxidation Dry milling Attrition milling 1 Introduction With the recent development of industrial technologies, increased atmospheric pollution has become a global social problem. Among the pollutants, NH3 emissions are generated from various chemical facilities, livestock operations, sewage treatment plants, and selective catalytic reduction (SCR). Certain techniques for removing NH3 have been developed such as adsorption, chemical treatment, catalytic decomposition, and selective catalytic oxidation (SCO). Techniques for removing NH3 via SCO using catalysts that convert NH3 into N2 are particularly attractive. In recent years, many studies have been carried out on SCO, and noble metal-based catalysts such as RuO2 [1], Ag/Al2O3 [2], Au/CeO2/Al2O3 [3], and Pt/CuO/Al2O3 [4] have been widely studied. These catalysts exhibit excellent performance for ammonia removal at 250°C. However, the cost of such systems is generally high, and the converted NH3 is oxidized into NO x (NO, NO2, and N2O), thereby posing the problem of generation of secondary pollutants. Studies on SCO reaction using metal oxide catalysts, such as MnO2 [5], MoO3 [6], CuO [7], Fe2O3 [8], and CoO3 [9], have reported high SCO activity at 400°C or higher; however, the catalytic activity of these metal oxides declines at lower temperatures. The V2O5-based catalyst, which is widely used in the SCR process, has also been applied to the conversion of NH3 into N2 [10]. The equation for the conversion of NH3 into N2 in the presence of oxygen can be expressed as follows: (1) NH3 →NH3 + +e− (2) NH3 + +O2 →NH3O2 (3) NH3O2 →H2NO2 +H+ (4) H2NO2 +H+ →H2NO2H+ (5) H2NO2H+ →HNOOH+H+ (6) HNOOH→NO+H2O (7) 4NO+4NH3 +O2 (internal SCR)→4N2 +6H2O The SCO reaction with V2O5-based catalysts is possible. However, because the reaction occurs at 400°C or higher and conversion of NH3 to NO x is likely [11], it is difficult to apply this reaction in practice. The development of a system with excellent NH3 removal efficiency at temperatures below 300°C, similar to noble metal catalysts that react at low temperature (at 250°C), and that concomitantly exhibits excellent N2 selectivity is thus required. Attempts have been made to increase the activity of catalysts by adjusting the primary crystallite size of the catalyst. Panagiotopoulou et al. [12] reported that the activity of Pt/TiO2 catalysts with various properties, applied to the water gas shift (WGS) reaction, was affected by the primary crystallite size of TiO2. Kim et al. [13,14] demonstrated that the primary crystallite size of the catalyst, determined via XRD analysis, was a major factor influencing the catalyst activity. With a smaller primary crystallite size, the turnover frequencies (TOFs) increased. Pourghahramani et al. [15] reported that as the primary crystallite size decreased, the density of hydroxyl groups increased as a result of the application of hematite in the milling process. Additionally, focus was placed on the effects of milling on the activity of catalysts used for oxidation–dehydrogenation [16,17] in hydrogen storage systems and the dehydration on mesoporous silica [18,19] in proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs). Herein, we evaluate non-noble metal-based catalysts for achieving excellent NH3 removal efficiency and N2 selectivity at temperatures below 300°C. A mechanochemical method is utilized to adjust the primary crystallite size of the V2O5/TiO2 catalyst prepared by an attrition milling process via combination of V2O5 powder and anatase TiO2 powder under dry conditions. The dry attrition milling method is utilized to enhance the oxidative properties of the catalyst and promote the NH3 removal efficiency at low temperatures, i.e., below 300°C. Furthermore, the milling time is controlled to increase the N2 selectivity in the SCO reaction. Analyses of the physicochemical characteristics of the catalysts are performed to examine the changes in the characteristics of the catalysts based on milling time using XRD, TEM, BET, NH3-TPD, and XPS analyses. 2 Experiments 2.1 Preparation of catalysts VTi-Mixed catalysts were prepared by mortar mixing of V2O5 (Aldrich Chemical Co.), based on 2wt% vanadium, and anatase TiO2 powder (Millennium Chemical Co.). The mixture was calcined in air for 4h at 400°C [20]. VTi-A.M catalysts were prepared by dry attrition milling (where A.M in the catalyst name denotes attrition milling). Anatase TiO2 powder and V2O5 powder, based on 1–4wt% vanadium, were placed in the attrition milling equipment with a zirconium ball (5mm in diameter). Here, the ball-to-powder mass ratio (BPMR) was 50:1, the milling speed was 500rpm, and the samples were milled for 1, 2, 3, 5, or 10h. The mixture was calcined in air for 4h at 400°C. “VTi-A.M” refers to all catalysts prepared by dry attrition milling, and the number at the end of “VTi-A.Mx” is the milling time applied. The initial number in “yVTi A.M” indicates the vanadium content (wt%). When the initial number (y) is omitted, the vanadium content is 2wt%. VTi-Imp catalysts were prepared by a wet impregnation process using ammonium metavanadate (NH4VO3, Aldrich Chemical Co.), based on 1–4wt% vanadium, and anatase TiO2 powder. The calculated amount of NH4VO3 was dissolved in distilled water and heated to 60°C. Because the solubility of NH4VO3 is very low, small volumes of oxalic acid ((COOH)2, Aldrich Chemical Co.) were added slowly to the ammonium vanadium aqueous solution while stirring until pH 2.5 was reached. The calculated amount of TiO2 was added to the solution. The mixture was agitated in the slurry state for over 1h, the moisture was then evaporated at 70°C using a rotary vacuum evaporator, and the mixture was dried overnight at 110°C. Subsequently, the mixture was calcined in air for 4h at 400°C [20]. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The structure of the catalysts was examined by X-ray diffraction (PANalytical X’Pert Pro MPD diffractometer) using Cu Kα radiation. Diffraction peaks, which were recorded in the 2θ range of 10–80° (4°/min), were used to identify the structure of the sample. The primary crystallite size of TiO2 was calculated using the Scherrer equation: (8) d = 0.9 λ B cos θ where λ is the X-ray wavelength corresponding to Cu Kα radiation, B is the broadening of the anatase (101) reflection, and θ is the angle of diffraction corresponding to the peak broadening. The surface areas of the samples were measured by physical nitrogen adsorption at −196°C (Micrometrics, ASAP 2010). The specific surface area was analyzed using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) model, and the average pore size was analyzed by using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) model. Prior to measurements, the catalysts (300mg) were degassed at 300°C for 2h. Field-emission transmission electron microscopy (FE-TEM) images were recorded with a JEM-2100F (JEOL) microscope, operated at an acceleration voltage of 200keV. Samples for FE-TEM measurements were prepared by suspending an ultrasonically treated catalyst powder sample in ethanol and placing a drop of the suspension onto a Cu grid. NH3 temperature programmed desorption (TPD) measurements were carried out with 300mg of the sample at a total flow rate of 50 cc/min. Prior to TPD measurements, the catalyst was pretreated in a flow of 5% O2/Ar at 400°C for 0.5h, followed by cooling to 50°C. The samples were then treated with 1% NH3/Ar for 1h. Surface NH3 was removed by sparging with Ar for 1h before starting the TPD experiments. During the TPD experiments, NH3 (m/z 15) was monitored continuously using a quadrupole mass spectrometer (QMS 422) while increasing the temperature to 600°C at a rate of 10°C/min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed using an ESCALAB 210 (VG Scientific) instrument, and monochromated Al Kα (1486.6eV) was used as an excitation source. After complete removal of moisture contained in the samples by drying at around 100°C for 24h, the samples were analyzed without surface sputtering and etching to maintain the vacuum pressure of the XPS equipment at 10−6 Pa. The binding energy and intensity of V 2p, Ti 2p, O 1s, and C 1s in the specimens were analyzed based on a wide scanning spectrum. Sample charge effects were eliminated by correcting the observed spectra using the C 1s binding energy (BE) value of 284.6eV. The temperature programmed reduction (TPR) of H2 was measured using 10% H2/Ar and 300mg of the catalyst at a total flow rate of 50cm3/min. Prior to H2-TPR measurements, the catalyst was pretreated in a flow of 5% O2/Ar at 400°C for 0.5h, followed by cooling to 50°C. The catalyst was placed in dilute hydrogen, and the consumption of hydrogen was monitored with an Autochem 2920 (Micrometrics) instrument while increasing the temperature to 600°C at a rate of 10°C/min. 2.3 Catalyst activity measurement Measurements of the SCO activity were carried out in a fixed-bed quartz reactor (i.d.: 8mm, height: 650mm). The amount of gas supplied to the reactor was regulated using a mass flow controller (Mass Flow Controller, MKS Co.) with individual cylinders of Ar, O2, and NH3. The reaction conditions were as follows: 850ppm NH3, 3vol% O2, 6vol% H2O, balance Ar, and 600mL/min total flow rate. Water was supplied to the reactor in conjunction with Ar injection through a bubbler. The concentration of NO was measured using a non-dispersive infrared absorption (NDIR) gas analyzer (ZKJ-2; Fuji Electric Co., Ltd., Japan); N2O was measured using an Ultramat 6 (Siemens Co.) instrument before the gases were allowed to flow into the analyzers, and the NO2 (9L: NO2) and ammonia concentrations (3M, 3La, 3L: NH3) were measured using a detector tube (GASTEC Co., Japan). Moisture was removed by a moisture trap inside the chiller. All data were collected at 60min (steady state) at the selected temperature. From the concentration of the gases at steady state, the conversion and N2 yield were calculated according to the following equations: (9) NH 3 removal efficicency ( % ) = [ NH 3 ] in − [ NH 3 ] out [ NH 3 ] in × 100 (10) N 2 yield ( % ) = [ NH 3 ] in − [ NH 3 ] out − [ NO ] out − [ NO 2 ] out − 2 [ N 2 O ] out [ NH 3 ] in × 100 In addition, reaction rates were calculated using the following expression: (11) r = X × F NH 3 W where r is the reaction rate of NH3 (μmol/s/g cat), F NH 3 is the total flow rate (μmol/s), W is the mass of catalyst (g), and X is the N2 yield of NH3, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 SCO activity of catalysts prepared using different attrition milling times The NH3 removal efficiency and N2 yield achieved with VTi-A.Mx prepared by attrition milling based on different times, mortar-mixed VTi-Mixed, and VTi-Imp, prepared by a wet impregnation method, were evaluated. As shown in Fig. 1(a), the NH3 removal efficiency achieved with the VTi-Mixed catalyst was very low at a space velocity of 60,000h−1. The catalysts could be ranked in the following order based on the NH3 removal efficiency at 250°C: VTi-A.M10>VTi-A.M5>VTi-A.M3>VTi-A.M2>VTi-A.M1>VTi-Imp>VTi-Mixed. However, as shown in Fig. 1(b), based on the N2 yield at 250°C, the order was: VTi-A.M3>VTi-A.M5>VTi-A.M10>VTi-A.M2>VTi-A.M1>VTi-Imp>VTi-Mixed. Thus, the SCO reaction activity of the catalysts prepared by attrition milling was superior to that of the catalysts prepared by mortar mixing and the wet impregnation method. The NH3 removal efficiency and N2 yield of the xVTi-A.M3 samples with different vanadium loadings prepared by attrition milling was also compared. As shown in Fig. 2(a), the NH3 removal efficiency increased until the amount of vanadium reached 4wt% in xVTi-A.My and xVTi-Imp catalysts, at a space velocity of 60,000h−1. xVTi-Imp indicates a low NH3 removal efficiency compared to the xVTi-A.M3 at the same vanadium loading. On the other hand, as shown in Fig. 2(b), the catalysts could be ranked in the following order based on the N2 yield at 250°C: 2VTi-A.M3>3VTi-A.M3>4VTi-A.M3>1VTi-A.M3>4VTi-Imp≈3VTi-Imp>2VTi-Imp>1VTi-Imp. The catalyst prepared by attrition milling with a vanadium loading of 2wt% gave rise to the highest N2 yield at 250–300°C. Fig. 3 shows the NH3 removal efficiency and N2 yield obtained with the catalysts prepared using various milling times at 250°C. The NH3 removal efficiency achieved with the catalysts increased with increasing attrition milling time. However, the highest N2 yield of 82% was obtained with the catalyst milled for 3h; the N2 yield decreased when the milling time was further increased. Thus, the optimal milling time for maximizing the N2 yield was determined to be 3h. 3.2 BET surface area, XRD, and TEM analysis Generally, the reactivity of a catalyst is determined by the surface properties of the catalyst. The mechanochemical treatment is a milling process/method that changes the characteristics of the catalyst. This method is in fact used to prepare nanocrystalline materials, and reportedly has a significant impact on the structure and reactivity due to high energy transfer to the material [21–24]. Table 1 shows the total pore volume, average pore diameter, surface area, and the crystallite size of TiO2 in the VTi-Mixed, VTi-A.Mx, and VTi-Imp samples. The total pore volume and average pore diameter of VTi-A.Mx generally declined due to the attrition milling effect. Fig. 4 shows the BJH pore size distributions of TiO2, VTi-Mixed, VTi-A.Mx, and VTi-Imp. The pore size distributions of TiO2, VTi-Mixed, and VTi-Imp were centered around 10nm. In the case of VTi-A.M1 where milling was applied, the pore size distribution was centered around 10–15nm. No prominent peaks were found in the pore size distributions of VTi-A.M3 and VTi-A.M10. The structural characteristics of the catalysts were analyzed by means of XRD. Fig. 5 shows the XRD patterns of VTi-Imp, VTi-Mixed, and VTi-A.Mx. The intensity of the anatase (101) peak was clearly reduced with increased milling time (standard material was catalyst mixed with YSZ (111) at 10wt%). Due to occurrence of phase transition in the case of VTi-A.M1, a peak corresponding to TiO2(II) was observed. Coste et al. [25] noted that anatase had a tendency to undergo transition to TiO2(II) and rutile, which are more stable towards external stimuli, because anatase is a metastable phase. V2O5 peaks (20.3, 26.1°) were observed in the XRD pattern of VTi-Mixed due to incomplete reaction of the V2O5 powder and TiO2. However, because no V2O5 peak was observed for the sample subjected to 1h of milling, it was deduced that V2O5 on the surface of the catalyst was dispersed on TiO2. The crystallite size of TiO2 (101) was calculated from the XRD data (Table 1), and indicated a clear reduction with increased milling time. Fig. 6 shows the relationship between the N2 yield and the size of the TiO2 crystallites in the V/Ti catalysts. The size of the TiO2 crystallites in the VTi-Mixed sample was 22nm. As the crystallite size was gradually reduced, the N2 yield increased. The maximal activity in terms of N2 yield was achieved with the V/Ti catalyst having an optimal TiO2 crystallite size of 16nm. The N2 yield tended to decrease when the TiO2 crystallite size was smaller than 16nm. In addition, the surface area clearly tended to decline with the attrition milling effect. The relationship between the NH3 removal efficiency and N2 yield versus the surface area is shown in Fig. 7 . The NH3 removal efficiency increased with a decrease of the surface area. The N2 yield gradually increased with a decrease of the surface area, but tended to decrease when the surface area was less than 43m2/g. The reaction rate showed the excellent value of 1.14μmol/s/g in the surface area of 43m2/g, and gradually decreased when the surface area was more than 43m2/g. Generally, because the particle size decreases in conjunction with the reduction of the crystallite size due to milling, the surface area also increases [15]. However, the crystallite size and the surface area of VTi-A.Mx were concomitantly reduced with increased milling time. As documented by Jentoft et al. [26], anatase TiO2 undergoes phase transition and the surface area is reduced with increased milling time. Thus, it is proposed that the crystallite size and surface area were reduced in this study as a result of the phase transition from anatase to TiO2(II). High-energy milling induced changes in the physical characteristics of the catalyst, such as the surface area and crystallite size of TiO2 (101), due to disruption of anatase TiO2. TEM images of VTi-Mixed, VTi-Imp, VTi-A.M1, VTi-A.M3, and VTi-A.M10 are presented in Fig. 8(a–e). The morphology of these oxides seems to be configured by a stack of spherical particles. TEM analysis shows that the particle size of VTi-Mixed and VTi-Imp was similar. The particle size declined gradually with increasing milling time. From the TEM analysis, the catalysts could be ranked in the following order based on the particle size: VTi-Mixed≈VTi-Imp>VTi-A.M1>VTi-A.M3>VTi-A.M1. This tendency was consistent with the evaluation (Table 1) of the crystallite size of TiO2 (101). 3.3 Temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) study The first step in performing the SCO reaction involves adsorption of atmospheric NH3 on the acid sites of the catalyst surface. The adsorption amount and adsorption pattern of NH3 are considered to be important. To investigate the variation in the strength of the acidic sites and the properties of NH3 adsorption on the catalysts with attrition milling time, NH3 temperature-programmed desorption experiments were performed using mass spectrometry. NH3 was monitored at m/z =15 during the NH3 TPD experiments. The results of the NH3-TPD analyses using VTi-Mixed, VTi-Imp, and VTi-A.Mx are shown in Fig. 9 . The profiles for all of the catalysts contained two broad NH3 desorption peaks at 80–200 and 230–400°C, attributed to the Brönsted and Lewis acid sites, respectively. It is known that ammonia adsorbed on Brönsted acid sites is desorbed at lower temperatures than that on Lewis acid sites [9,27]. For V2O5/TiO2 catalysts, ammonia is reportedly desorbed from the Brönsted acid sites with an activation energy of 12–14kcal/mol and from the Lewis acid sites with an activation energy of 24–27kcal/mol [28]. The present NH3-TPD analysis shows that the NH3 desorption peak was the largest in the temperature range of 80–400°C for the sample prepared using an attrition milling time of 3h. It appears that milling induced an increase in the number of Brönsted and Lewis acid sites on the catalyst surface with the use of a milling time of up to 3h. The total acidity (mmol/m2) was calculated from the desorption peak to compare the amount of NH3 adsorbed on the acid sites of the catalysts; the results are shown in Table 2 . From these results, the VTi-A.M3 catalyst had the highest acidity, indicating that vanadium was dispersed on the catalyst surface by milling. Kwon et al. [20] reported an increase in the V/Ti ratio of the catalyst surface due to milling, which means that the acid sites increase as vanadium becomes more highly dispersed on the catalyst surface due to attrition milling. Wang et al. [29] demonstrated that a high intensity peak is generated in the NH3-TPD profile of finely dispersed metal oxide species on the catalyst surface, and that the finely dispersed metal oxide species are the main sites of adsorption of NH3 molecules. The amount of ammonia adsorbed is related to the active sites exposed on the surface and the surface area of the catalyst. Although, the areas of the desorption peaks for the VTi-Imp and VTi-A.M1 catalysts were calculated to be similar, the VTi-A.M1 catalyst had better SCO reactivity than the VTi-Imp catalyst. An increase in the area of the desorption peak had a positive effect on the SCO reaction, but was not directly correlated with the N2 yield. 3.4 XPS study X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed to investigate the correlation between the SCO activity and the valence state characteristics of the V2O5/TiO2 catalysts. The binding energies of atoms have distinct values, and the valence states of atoms such as V, Ti, O, and C can be determined from the binding energy peaks in the range of 0–1480eV. Representative peaks of the atoms were detected using a narrow scan and the peaks were analyzed to determine the characteristics of each atom. Fig. 10 shows the deconvoluted O 1s spectra of the VTi-Mixed, VTi-Imp, VTi-A.M1, VTi-A.M3, and VTi-A.M10 catalysts. The O 1s peak was fitted into sub-bands by searching for the optimum combination of Gaussian bands. The sub-bands at 529.5–530.0eV are attributable to lattice O2− oxygen (expressed as Oβ) [30]. The two bands at 531.0–531.6eV and 532.8–533.0eV are respectively assigned to surface-adsorbed oxygen (Oα), such as O2 2− and O−, associated with chemisorbed water (expressed as O ′ α ) [31,32]. The percentage of Oα species increased with application of attrition milling. The VTi-Mixed (26.8%) sample had the lowest Oα ratio, and increasingly higher ratios were observed for VTi-Imp (33.6%), VTi-A.M1 (40.4%), VTi-A.M3 (45.3%), and VTi-A.M10 (48.4%). Wu et al. [33] reported that surface-chemisorbed oxygen (Oα) is the most active oxygen species, and is highly active in the oxidation reaction due to its higher mobility. Thus, the increase in surface chemisorbed oxygen (Oα) was closely associated with NH3 oxidation, and was consistent with the NH3 removal efficiency of the catalysts presented in Fig. 1(a). Thus, the increase in the O α / ( O α + O ′ α + O β ) ratio was correlated to the increase in NH3 oxidation in the SCO reaction, but was not associated with the N2 yield. Fig. 11 shows the deconvoluted V 2p spectra for the VTi-Mixed, VTi-Imp, VTi-A.M1, VTi-A.M3, and VTi-A.M10 catalysts. From the V 2p peak of the VTi-Mixed catalyst, vanadium apparently existed only in the V5+ state. However, vanadium was present in the VTi-Imp and VTi-AM catalysts as V5+, V4 +, and V3+. As shown in Table 2, the peak area ratio of V5+ in the V/Ti catalyst varied based on the milling time. The highest V5+ peak area ratio was observed for VTi-A.M3. High-energy impact was generated in the course of catalyst preparation by the dry attrition milling method. Thus, the increase in V5+ species on the catalyst surface indicates that V2O5 is highly dispersed by milling. In the case of VTi-A.M10, fewer V5+ vanadium species were present relative to that in VTi-A.M3. It is proposed that there was a change in the valence state of vanadium from V5+ to V4+ or V3+ induced by high-energy milling. The (V4+ +V3+) peak area ratio of the V/Ti catalysts determined by XPS is shown in Table 2. The content of V4+ and V3+ species (from V2O5/TiO2) on the catalyst surface increased due to mechanochemical milling [34–36]. The reduction in the valence state of the vanadium species plausibly occurs by excision of the oxygen bond due to V2O5 and TiO2 disruption by the attrition milling effect. The correlation between V5+ on the catalyst surface and the SCO activity was evaluated based on the N2 yield and reaction rate as shown in Fig. 12 . The higher the content of V5+ vanadium species on the catalyst surface, the higher the N2 yield and reaction rate. According to Yuan et al. [10], the presence of oxygen in V2O5 (010) promotes the internal SCR reaction due to oxidation of NH3 to NO via SCO mechanisms. In the case of VTi-A.M3, the observed excellent selective catalytic oxidation of NH3 was attributed to active internal SCR reaction given that V5+ species are highly dispersed on the catalyst surface. Operation of the internal SCR effect was investigated for VTi-A.M3 and VTi-A.M10, which show excellent activity in terms of the NH3 removal efficiency and N2 yield in the SCO reaction. As shown in Fig. 13 , NO to N2 conversion was observed with VTi-A.M3 and VTi-A.M10 at 200–300°C (GHSV=60,000h−1). The VTi-A.M10 catalyst exhibited extremely low SCR activity where NH3 used as the reductant in the SCR reaction was oxidized to NO x . Furthermore, VTi-A.M3 exhibited superior SCR activity relative to VTi-A.M10, which implies that the SCR reaction of NO+NH3 +O2 proceeds on the catalyst surface. Therefore, VTi-A.M3 exhibited excellent activity for the SCO reaction as indicated by the internal SCR reaction effect. Thus, the dry attrition milling method can be used to control the dispersion of vanadium on the surface, thereby improving the N2 yield and reaction rate by increasing the content of V5+ species. Additionally, the increased ratio of V5+ was the rate-determining parameter in the selective oxidation reaction of ammonia. 3.5 H2-TPR study H2-TPR experiments were performed to investigate the oxidation state of vanadium oxides and the reducibility of the catalysts. Fig. 14 shows the H2-TPR profile of the TiO2 and V/Ti catalysts. The maximum temperature of hydrogen consumption (T max) of TiO2 was 512.10°C. The peak temperature of hydrogen consumption for VTi-Mixed was 504.68°C, which is slightly lower than that of TiO2. The vanadium species of VTi-Mixed are present in the V5+ state based on the XPS results. Although the peak area corresponding to V5+ species in the XPS profiles was rather small, the occurrence of T max at high temperature was attributed to the observation of the original peak of V2O5 or TiO2 due to imperfect union of V2O5 and TiO2. This peak may be a low intensity reduction peak for conversion of Ti4+ to Ti3+ in TiO2 after bulk V2O5 on the surface had been reduced by hydrogen. In previous studies reported in the literature, the high-temperature reduction peak is generally attributed to the reduction of vanadium in polymeric and bulk-like V2O5 species [37–40]. The T max occurred at 376.88, 388.28, 417.12, and 413.25°C, respectively, with VTi-Imp, VTi-A.M1, VTi-A.M3, and VTi-A.M10. Comparison of the reduction properties of the V/Ti catalyst and pure TiO2 shows a shift of the reduction temperature of the V/Ti catalyst to lower temperature, plausibly due to the interaction between V2O5 and TiO2. The T max of the V/Ti catalysts appeared at high temperature, consistent with the order of the V5+ peak area from XPS analysis as follows: (V5+ peak area ratio by XPS analysis): VTi-A.M3 (1.17)>VTi-A.M10 (1.09)>VTi-A.M1 (1.05)>VTi-Imp (1.00). In addition, the low temperature reduction peak has been shown to represent monomeric species or highly dispersed vanadium species [41–43]. The observed decrease in T max (from H2-TPR analysis) with increasing attrition milling time is attributed to transformation of the crystallite V2O5 species into monomeric species during ball milling due to the interaction between V2O5 and TiO2. In the case of VTi-A.M1 and VTi-A.M3, H2 consumption occurred at a relatively lower temperature due to the increase in the content of V4+ and V3+ species. Furthermore, H2 consumption was detected at 100–280°C with the use of VTi-A.M10, which is possibly caused by phase transition of anatase type TiO2 to TiO2(II). Due to this phenomenon, excellent oxidation efficiency was achieved at low temperature. The V/Ti catalysts can be ranked as follows based on H2 consumption: VTi-A.M3 (847μmol/g)>VTi-A.M10 (758μmol/g)>VTi-A.M1 (486μmol/g)>VTi-Imp (481μmol/g)>VTi-Mixed (441μmol/g). The VTi-A.M3 catalyst gave rise to an excellent N2 yield with the highest value of 847μmol/g. In contrast, the lowest H2 consumption of 441μmol/g was observed with the VTi-Mixed catalyst. For this reason, oxygen release from VTi-Mixed was more difficult. In brief, the interaction between V2O5 and TiO2 has a significant influence on the catalyst reducibility, and the catalyst reducibility largely depends on the attrition milling time. The VTi-A.M3 catalysts possessed many surface oxygen species combined with vanadium species. The results revealed that high oxygen mobility was an important factor in the SCO reaction. 4 Conclusions Metal oxide catalysts generally exhibit adequate NH3 removal efficiency at temperatures higher than 400°C. Herein, the dry attrition milling method was applied to enhance catalytic oxidation, and excellent NH3 removal efficiency was achieved at 250°C. By controlling the milling time, the N2 selectivity of the catalysts in the SCO reaction was enhanced. An excellent SCO catalyst with an N2 yield of 82% at 250°C was developed. From evaluation of the effects of the crystalline structure and valence state of vanadium in the catalysts prepared by the dry attrition milling method on the SCO reaction, the ensuing deductions could be made. Unlike the VTi-Mixed catalyst, no V2O5 peak was observed in the XRD analysis of the VTi-A.M catalyst processed using attrition milling. Phase transition from anatase TiO2 to TiO2(II) was observed with increased milling time, and the crystallite size of TiO2 (101) decreased. The highest N2 yield was achieved with the catalyst having a TiO2 crystallite size of 16nm. Based on NH3-TPD analysis, the VTi-A.M3 catalyst had the highest acidity. XPS analysis demonstrated an increase of the surface-adsorbed oxygen species and V5+ vanadium species, and the presence of reduced vanadium species, due to attrition milling. The increase in the content of V5+ species and the N2 yield are directly related. The increased content of V5+ species was the rate-determining parameter in the selective oxidation reaction of ammonia. Accordingly, dry attrition milling can be applied as a dry synthesis method for the preparation of SCO catalysts using V2O5 and TiO2 in the powder phase. References [1] S. Hong A. Karim T.S. coredata.dc:description: Mechanochemical treatments can change the physicochemical characteristics of catalysts. Attrition milling was utilized in the preparation of catalysts from V2O5 and anatase TiO2, and the catalysts were applied for the study of selective catalytic oxidation (SCO). Catalysts comprising 2wt% V/Ti were prepared by mechanochemical methods using different milling times, and these catalysts were used for the SCO of NH3 to N2. The optimal calcination milling time was 3h. The 2wt% V/Ti catalyst prepared by attrition milling for 3h (VTi-A.M3; where A.M in the catalyst name denotes attrition milling, and 3 is the milling time applied) gave rise to the highest N2 yield (∼82%) at 250°C. The dry attrition milling method is a dry method for the synthesis of the SCO catalyst, involving a combination of V2O5 and TiO2 powder. The properties of the catalyst were studied using physiochemical analyses, including BET surface area, X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR). Anatase, which is a metastable phase, underwent transformation into TiO2(II) due to the milling effect. The highest N2 yield was achieved when the TiO2 crystallite size of the catalyst was 16nm. The content of pentavalent vanadium species increased due to the milling effect. A correlation was identified between the V5+ species and the catalyst N2 yield. VTi-A.M3 was found to lead to high-level selective catalytic oxidation of NH3, with active internal selective catalytic reduction (SCR) because of the presence of highly dispersed V5+ on the catalyst surface. The dry attrition milling method can be used to control the dispersion of vanadium on the catalyst surface, which can in turn improve the N2 yield activity by increasing the ratio of V5+ species.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of attrition milling on V/Ti catalysts for the selective oxidation of ammonia
